description: {"blocks":[{"key":"jkfv","text":"High-throughput measurement of cells perturbed using libraries of small molecules, gene knockouts, or different microenvironmental factors is a key step in functional genomics and pre-clinical drug discovery. However, it remains difficult to perform accurate single-cell assays in 384-well plates, limiting many studies to well-average measurements (e.g. CellTiter-Glo®). Here, a public domain “Dye Drop” method that uses sequential density displacement and microscopy to perform cell count and viability assays is described. Cell viability and DNA replication assays are followed by immunofluorescence imaging to collect single-cell dose-response data in the \"Deep Dye Drop\" version of the protocol. The resultant data can be used to calculate growth rate inhibition (GR) values and metrics. Dye Drop is rapid, reproducible, customizable, and compatible with manual or automated laboratory equipment. Dye Drop improves the tradeoff between data content and cost, enabling the collection of information-rich perturbagen-response datasets.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
keywords: High-throughput microscopy, live-cell assays, dose response, small molecule perturbation, viability, cell cycle,GR metrics

{"blocks":[{"key":"3g80v","text":"Image Acquisition:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":18}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5rji4","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a3s5f","text":"On the Operetta:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d1phn","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"apj9v","text":"Hoechst (ex 360-400 em 410-480)

pH3-A488 (ex 460-490 em 500-550)

{"blocks":[{"key":"6d3oh","text":"Image Analysis\n","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":14}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"82lod","text":"Apply flat field correction if available","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5pp7l","text":"Segment nuclei based on Hoechst signal","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"211mk","text":"Define a ring around the nuclei, be sure this does not include any of the nuclear area (it will be used to subtract the  local background from each channel)","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7v5c","text":"calculate the nuclear area","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":14,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4f5ri","text":"for each channel, calculate the average intensities within the nuclear mask, and within the surrounding ring","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4l93u","text":"for each channel, subtract the ring intensity from the nuclear intensity","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":72}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9vaob","text":"multiply the nuclear area by the Hoechst intensity for the DNA content","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":58,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"hpar","text":"calculate SER spot pixel size 8 texture feature for the LDR signal within the nuclear area","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":10,"length":37}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"237ep","text":"output features (nuclear area,DNA content, Hoechst, EdU, pH3, LDR background corrected intensities, LDR texture feature)in a .tsv file","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"brhct","text":"identify cells in mitosis through pH3 intensity","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cv3di","text":"identify dead cells though LDR intensity and/or texture- threshold independent of cell line","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"43rag","text":"identify additional dead cells through size (small) and intensity (high)- optimize per cell line","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"71km9","text":"identify population of cells in each phase of the cell cycle based on DNA content and EdU intensity","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4m8bk","text":"identify additional dead cells based on size (small) and intensity (high)","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
